channel.title: Fighting?
channel.description:
Well, I was talking to a bunch of my mates today about fighting and stuff (not the talk like, "I'm going to bash such and such"), more talking about why there are certain acts that are looked down in a fight, example kicking.
A lot of people think kicking in a fight is "girlish", but I don't understand why, kicking is a LOT more powerful and effective than punching. But, apparently if you kick in a fight you're a girl? Which brings me to the main point in this topic:
Submission moves? I was just wanting to see what everyones views are on submissive moves and holds in fights. I, being a Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu fighter know how to use proper submission holds, but it's apparently "dog" in a fight? I can honestly say I would go for a submissive move if the person tried to street fight and tackle me or whatever, until then I would use my Muay Thai martial art skills.
I was just wondering what all of your views on it are.

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Cowie`, post:78, topic:239410”][quote author=jme link=topic=315700.msg2589827#msg2589827 date=1229713988]
when your on top of someone pounding the shit out of their face, you should learn to stop after a while.
[/quote]

Yeah, when they can’t fight back.[/quote]
Oh, I am all for that. When you have won, and they have submitted or asked for you to stop etc, then you should stop. Otherwise if you walk away, you’re getting a punch in the back of the head.

[quote=“Server-Unknown.Net, post:79, topic:239410”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=315700.msg2507962#msg2507962 date=1225101987]
Well, I was talking to a bunch of my mates today about fighting and stuff (not the talk like, “I’m going to bash such and such”), more talking about why there are certain acts that are looked down in a fight, example kicking.

A lot of people think kicking in a fight is “girlish”, but I don’t understand why, kicking is a LOT more powerful and effective than punching. But, apparently if you kick in a fight you’re a girl? Which brings me to the main point in this topic:

Submission moves? I was just wanting to see what everyones views are on submissive moves and holds in fights. I, being a Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu fighter know how to use proper submission holds, but it’s apparently “dog” in a fight? I can honestly say I would go for a submissive move if the person tried to street fight and tackle me or whatever, until then I would use my Muay Thai martial art skills.

I was just wondering what all of your views on it are.

[/quote]

Uhh… Well let me tell you, Kicking is considered a girl if you street fighting, outside of that combat style isnt. Just plain ol martial arts. But you can only kick if you do a good combo which is likely to never happen.[/quote]
Why would you say you need a combo. A simple roundhouse kick can produce more power than 4 big long arching punches. You don’t really combo with your legs, it’s simple. Use your hands to jab jab jab until they don’t see it coming. Big kick to the head, hitting in the right spot can cause devastating affects.

Read full topic

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

I’ve never seen a problem with fighting someone on the ground, infact I don’t think I’ve EVER seen a fight where it isn’t taken to the ground at some point.

Now, when your on top of someone pounding the shit out of their face, you should learn to stop after a while.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

Cowie` crush.

And you know, if it’s a serious enough fight and you walk away when you get them down. 80% of the time you’re getting a smack in the back of the head when you’re walking away.

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Zero187, post:72, topic:239410”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=315700.msg2580149#msg2580149 date=1229224840]

Yes there may be rules to a fight, even though they aren’t really stated or agreed upon anywhere. I’ll do my best to cover them:

  1. Always fight 1v1 unless it’s agreed upon otherwise.
  2. Don’t go for the balls, don’t poke in the eyes. A fight ain’t a fight if your opponent can’t move or see.
  3. Wait until your opponent is ready before attacking, a cheap punch will only show you have no confidence.
  4. Never draw a weapon unless agreed upon before hand (unless your opponent draws one unfairly)
  5. Don’t attack your opponent while he’s down. Once again, this shows lack of respect and lack of confidence. If you honestly think that you will lose unless you attack your opponent when down, then you deserve to lose!
  6. Respect your enemies, for victory is not certain and either one of you could end up on the ground crying.
  7. Finish a fight, but only if your opponent wants to finish it. There is no honor in attacking someone who does not intend to fight.
  8. Remember each rule can and will be broken, so always be prepared – for the wiseman’s greatest advantage is the distrust of his fellow man.

That’s bullshit, why can I not attack a man when he is on the ground? If I have gotten him to the ground, I intend to fight on the ground. There’s 3 places you can fight a fight, clinche, standup and the ground. Most people can do the first 2 easily, but fighting well on the ground is hard, fighting well on the ground is harder
[/quote]

If you both get to the ground and are wrestling then that’s obviously ok. No where did I say that was against the rules.
Attacking an opponent while he’s down simply means while he’s not fighting back. If you really want to argue for beating defenseless individuals, I doubt many will agree with you.[/quote]
I still do not understand why it is an unwritten rule to not an opponent while he’s defenseless, if I have struck him in the face and he falls to the ground, why can I not finish him? If I have opened his guard, why can I not finish?

Read full topic

@Zero187 wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:71, topic:239410”][quote author=Zero187 link=topic=315700.msg2579432#msg2579432 date=1229171270]
Yes there may be rules to a fight, even though they aren’t really stated or agreed upon anywhere. I’ll do my best to cover them:

  1. Always fight 1v1 unless it’s agreed upon otherwise.
  2. Don’t go for the balls, don’t poke in the eyes. A fight ain’t a fight if your opponent can’t move or see.
  3. Wait until your opponent is ready before attacking, a cheap punch will only show you have no confidence.
  4. Never draw a weapon unless agreed upon before hand (unless your opponent draws one unfairly)
  5. Don’t attack your opponent while he’s down. Once again, this shows lack of respect and lack of confidence. If you honestly think that you will lose unless you attack your opponent when down, then you deserve to lose!
  6. Respect your enemies, for victory is not certain and either one of you could end up on the ground crying.
  7. Finish a fight, but only if your opponent wants to finish it. There is no honor in attacking someone who does not intend to fight.
  8. Remember each rule can and will be broken, so always be prepared – for the wiseman’s greatest advantage is the distrust of his fellow man.
    [/quote]
    That’s bullshit, why can I not attack a man when he is on the ground? If I have gotten him to the ground, I intend to fight on the ground. There’s 3 places you can fight a fight, clinche, standup and the ground. Most people can do the first 2 easily, but fighting well on the ground is hard, fighting well on the ground is harder ;)[/quote]

If you both get to the ground and are wrestling then that’s obviously ok. No where did I say that was against the rules.
Attacking an opponent while he’s down simply means while he’s not fighting back. If you really want to argue for beating defenseless individuals, I doubt many will agree with you.

Read full topic

  8. Remember each rule can and will be broken, so always be prepared – for the wiseman’s greatest advantage is the distrust of his fellow man.[/quote]

There’s 3 places you can fight a fight, clinche, standup and the ground. Most people can do the first 2 easily, but fighting well on the ground is hard, fighting well on the ground is harder

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

If it’s a personal thing between me and someone else, and theres no reason to fight dirty, then I will not do it.

Almost all fights I enter are drug-deal related, or defending myself when I’ve been jumped. If someone jumps me and wants to steal my shit, I don’t care about fighting dirty I just care about leaving them as bloody and broken as I can without killing them and getting away safely.

I’m smaller and quite socially awkward around people I don’t know too well. This makes a lot of drug dealers think that they can take advantage of me. But then I return with my good 2 buddies who have my back and seriously it’s been pretty brutal sometimes what we’ve done heh. I probably get in a fight once a month, because of the people I am involved with mostly.

Read full topic

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @Wrauld Wrauld
item.description:
@Wrauld wrote:

Arms are attached to your body. Legs are attached to your body. Legs are stronger then your arms because you use them almost all the time.
Why not use the stronger muscle? How can you be a girl and kick their ass in a fight if you used your leg…

Read full topic

item.description:
@Zero187 wrote:

Yes there may be rules to a fight, even though they aren’t really stated or agreed upon anywhere. I’ll do my best to cover them:

  1. Always fight 1v1 unless it’s agreed upon otherwise.
  2. Don’t go for the balls, don’t poke in the eyes. A fight ain’t a fight if your opponent can’t move or see.
  3. Wait until your opponent is ready before attacking, a cheap punch will only show you have no confidence.
  4. Never draw a weapon unless agreed upon before hand (unless your opponent draws one unfairly)
  5. Don’t attack your opponent while he’s down. Once again, this shows lack of respect and lack of confidence. If you honestly think that you will lose unless you attack your opponent when down, then you deserve to lose!
  6. Respect your enemies, for victory is not certain and either one of you could end up on the ground crying.
  7. Finish a fight, but only if your opponent wants to finish it. There is no honor in attacking someone who does not intend to fight.
  8. Remember each rule can and will be broken, so always be prepared – for the wiseman’s greatest advantage is the distrust of his fellow man.

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:66, topic:239410”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=315700.msg2531472#msg2531472 date=1226476618]

If some guy says you’re a girl for kicking, kick their balls and see if they say that again

That is something I do not like, I see a low blow as a looked down act in a fight - however, in street fighting, go for it.

Well, if someone attacked me in the street the only thing I’d want to do is get away, so getting looked down upon for trying to defend myself and survive means shit to me, really.
[/quote]
Say someone who is huge, and you get him to the ground via a BJ take down method, which WILL bring anyone down, you’d think he’d just ground & pound his way to victory.[/quote]
lul blowjawb.

Read full topic

item.title: Fighting?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Kane., post:65, topic:239410”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=315700.msg2531430#msg2531430 date=1226470335]

If some guy says you’re a girl for kicking, kick their balls and see if they say that again

That is something I do not like, I see a low blow as a looked down act in a fight - however, in street fighting, go for it.
[/quote]
Well, if someone attacked me in the street the only thing I’d want to do is get away, so getting looked down upon for trying to defend myself and survive means shit to me, really.[/quote]
Agreed. But my point is, a lot of people think if someone is really tank and big they will pound the living day light out of you, which is why Jiu-Jitsu was revolutionalized by the Gracie brothers.

Say someone who is huge, and you get him to the ground via a BJJ take down method, which WILL bring anyone down, you’d think he’d just ground & pound his way to victory, but if you got him into your guard, he will lose all power in his strikes, and if this is the case, there is basically a Gator Choke, as he won’t be able to defend it.

Read full topic
